Good. You had me worried there. JACK brushes a strand of hair from her shoulder.
/ I’ll take a look at hin.  26

The room is oak-panelled, but it’s hard to notice because every square inch is covered with TROPHIES, MEDALS, and PHOTOS OF KATE SKATING SINCE SHE WAS FOUR. JACK sits behi his desk. DOUG, across from him, is slouched in an armcha

Let me tell you how I run my business: I hire the very best people I can get my hands on and I leave them alone until they disappoint me or I can find somebody better. You’ve heard of the Moscow Central Army Sports Club? (Doug nods) Anton was their pride and joy. When it comes to skating I don’t think there’s anybody who knows more. So I trust him. I have to. He says you’re something special. He tells me he can work around your eye problen. . (beat) What do you think?
I think you must be in pretty sad shape to come after me. JACK sits back. Off balance and not used to it.
So who else is in on this?
What do you mean by that?
When you’re done, do I have to go talk to mom and the rest of the family?
(flatly) Kate is an only child. Her mother died when she was six. JACK lets him hang there a moment.
Sorry. It’s been a long day.
You stay with us and you’ll have a lot of long days.  Ne A beat. JACK measures DOUG. JACK points to
I understand you and I have one thing in common.
What’s that?
I don't like to lose either. AN EMPTY GLASS DISPLAY CASE on his desk.

You see this? -- There’s an Olympic Gold medal belongs in there. We’re winners in this house. We’ve always been winners. Kate is a winner. (his eyes linger on the empty case) And this damn thing...this is our veminder of what happens when you hitch your wagon to a dud. (he looks up) See, Doug, pairs skating, more than anything else, is about trust. You trust that I’m gonna throw you high enough in the air, and I trust that when you come down, you’re not gonna put a blade in my back. I can never skate any better than you let me. DOUG stares back, stone-faced. A cipher.

Now Brian Newman could skate. And unlike you, he wasn’t a reclamation project. But you couldn’t trust him. He wasn’t what I’d call a pressure player. When the whip came down, Brian folded and Kate ended up looking like a fool. JACK lifts a stack of papers on his desk for DOUG to see. JACK balls the
These are scouting reports. Male skaters. Thirty-five wash-outs. (pulling the one on top) Wagner...no stamina. paper in his hand -- tosses it across his desk toward a garbage can -- missing.  23
(taking the next) Myersohn...no rhythm. JACK crumples this one -=- tosses it -- missing again.

(in quick succesion) Leone...Parnes...Hudler... (he misses all three, focuses on Doug) Are you a pressure player, Doug? Or is everyone wasting their time? Without a word, DOUG, leans forward, takes the next page on the stack, crushes it quickly in his hand and flips it effortlessly toward the garbage can -- THE PAPER arcs far across the room -- BING! Dead perfect.
Lucky shot.
I say I make it again. (he grins) Double or nothing my allowance. JACK smiles, pushes the stack toward him.
You’re on.
KATE at the keyhole -- a baffling silence. Suddenly, THE DOORS FLY OPEN -- JACK and DOUG exit the study, all smile
(putting an arm over Doug’s shoulder) Great to have you aboard, son! (looking up) Kate, there you are... KATE stares in horror at this tableau of fraternity.
Great meeting you, Jack... (he glances at Kate, smiles broadly) »--and I’11 catch your act tomorrow. cuT To:
29 INT. THE BUTLER’S BEDROOM Dark. Proper. MARTIN, the eldery butler, reading in bed, hears something -- looks up over bifocals.
Well... KATE, wearing a nightgown, steps into the room, closing t door furtively behind her. Silence. She stands there.
It’s been a while, hasn’t it? KATE nods. Something needy in her expression.
That bad? (she nods again) I’m an old man, Kate. (she shrugs) We'll be very tired in the morning.
I won’t tell if you won’t. MARTIN cuts the thinnest of smiles. KATE brightens.

MARTIN’S ROOM -- TWO HOURS LATER KATE and MARTIN sprawled on a couch, chastely bundled in nightclothes and blankets -= watching TV -~- popcorn, coo potato chips, strewn everywhere. KATE is weeping. MARTIN, huddled in robe and nightcap, looks pretty choked-up hims ACROSS THE ROOM -- ON TV -- A VIDEOTAPE runs the final, tear-stained moments of "Dark Victory." DISSOLVE To:

DOUG at center ice, staring straight ahead. ANTON, carryi a dozen plastic cones, stands with KATE off to one side. As this scene plays, ANTON, testing the perimeters of DOU visual problem, moves KATE around the ice.
We start here -- you are seeing her?
Nope. ANTON drops a cone, pulls KATE forward to the next positi
(calling over) If you’re so good, why didn’t you just skate solo? (silence, he turns--) ©
Eyes forward! (Doug turns back) You are seeing here? DOUG shakes his head no. ANTON drops a cone. They move on
It’s a reasonable question.
Tell him.
(grudgingly) I wouldn’t. do the compulsories.
You mean, those figure eights and stuff? Wouldn’t or couldn’t?
I detested the entire procedure.
(stopping) Compulsories require patience. (Kate shoots him a look) What about here?:
Got it. ANTON drops two cones, checking the angles. KATE breaks f
Talk about hiring the handicapped.
Hey, if we’re gonna work together, you might try and be polite.
You’re not going to be here long ~ enough to make it worth the effort.
Don’t think I/11 be able to put up with your shit?
(as she passes) I don’t think you can skate.
There’s only two things I do really well and skating’s one of them.
Grunting around the ice with a stick in your hand is not skating.
Honey, when it comes to hockey, you haven’t, got a clue. (beat) Aren’t you going to ask me what the second thing is?
God, you really are a neanderthal.
Sorry to disappoint you, but I’m from Minnesota. KATE stares over, incredulous. DOUG smiles -- he's joking
What do you do for fun? Polish your knife collection?

I’m sure there’s nothing I do that you’d find exciting. I don’t open beer bottles with my toes. I don’t sit around and count what’s left of my teeth. I don’t even enjoy watching a good tractor-pull. It’s a very limited existence, but I’ve gotten used to it.
Life of the party, huh? (he starts to stretch) Place must be crawling with guys.
(biting at this) For your information, I do have a boyfriend.
There’s a rough gig. What do you do, keep him chained in the basement?
Hale, at the moment, is working in my father’s London office. He’s an MBA. Harvard? Maybe you’ve heard of it, they have a hockey team.
Must be a very sharp guy. (she looks at hin, suspicious) I’1l bet. you look all right from a couple thousand miles away. cuUT TO:
Center ice. ANTON facing DOUG and KATE.
In hockey, everything is low. Center of gravity is low. Weight transfer is low. Shoulders are low.
You forgot intelligence.

(shooting her a look) Here, for us, everything is line. , Everything is grace. For pairs skating, is one thing means entire game: Man and woman together make flower. You, Douglas, are sten. Man is support, strength, fiber. Katya is petal. She is beauty, radiance, delicacy. Is flower, you understand? (language drifting) Tsvyeetoch’niy.

So what’s Russian for poison ivy? . cUuT TO: INT. DOUG’S BEDROOM -- BEFORE DAWN ANTON enters the dark room, hits the lights. DOUG, dead _ asleep pulls the blankets over his head and -- CUE MUSIC -- our TRAINING THEME -- we’re into a MONTAGE.
KATE, lacing up, watching ANTON work DOUG on the ice.
DOUG and ANTON running through the woods. The CAMERA PULL AHEAD -- KATE, way out front, looking fresh.
State-of-the-art. DOUG toiling at a Nautilus machine, glancing between reps at -- KATE, across the room, every hair in place, as she muscles a rowing machine.
A padded floor. KATE in mid-air, hanging by a LEATHER HARNESS as ANTON demonstrates a lift for DOUG.
INT. ANTON’S APARTMENT -- NIGHT The mirror image of DOUG’S upstairs studio. ANTON eats. DOUG, head down on the table, is dead asleep.
Center ice. KATE stahding stoically. DOUG staring at ANTO
You want my hands where? ANTON points. KATE braces. DOUG exhales, shakes his head, and slips his hand gingerly between KATE’s legs.

A QUICK SERIES OF FALLS -- changes of clothing evidence t these are happening over a period of weeks. KATE falls... DOUG slips... KATE trips up DOUG... DOUG trips over KATE... KATE and DOUG collide...
DOUG pulls off a WORN-OUT, BEATEN SKATE and hands it to ANTON for his inspection. ANTON shakes his head.
A STREAM OF SPARKS pouring from a GRINDING WHEEL as a SKA BLADE, being sharpened, strains against the stone.  34

KATE and ANTON stand back as an OLD CRAFTSMAN works the w This place is clearly a landmark -- a century’s worth of and grime coats the entire cluttered space. DOUG, off to one side, stares at the WALL -- covered with hundreds of yellowing, autographed PHOTOGRAPHS of skaters who’ve journeyed here over the years. boUuG . (reading the names) Lutz...Axel...Sal-chow... He looks up to see ANTON watching hin.
You mean these moves are named after actual people? Before ANTON can answer, the CRAFTSMAN, turns sharply --

It’s Sal-kow. Ulrich Salchow. (eyes boring on Doug) The world didn’t start last week, young man. DOUG swallows. The CRAFTSMAN shakes his head ‘with disgus turns back to the wheel. ANTON gestures for KATE and DOUG to leave -- .
Why don’t I meet you across the street?
KATE and DOUG seated in this elegant little bistro, silen examining menus. A WAITER sides to the table.
You’re waiting for a third party?
Yes, but we’1ll go ahead.
I’ll have -- Madam -- KATE stares at DOUG, then turns to the WAITER.
I’d like the aparagus and the Calamari Salad. Four wedges of lemon. No dressing. No oil. The WAITER scribbles, turns to DOUG --
Is there a burger on here? (Kate groans) . You have a problem? KATE . No. You have the problen. The WAITER stands-by uncomfortably.
(to the Waiter) Blind date. (staring at Kate as he orders) I'd like a cheeseburger, a well- done, friendly, all-American, missionary-position, cheeseburger please.
I’m afraid, sir, that we don’t have any ground beef in the house this afternoon.
(to the’ Waiter) Food frightens him. He talks tough but he’s actually a very timid young man. DOUG glares. THE WAITER looks back and forth nervously.
Just bring me what she’s having.
The Calamari, sir?
Sure. - Just make mine well done.
Well done isn’t really -
I’d love to see your expression, but it’s not worth wasting the meal. You just ordered squid salad.
(challenged now) You think I won’t eat squid?
I don’t think you can spell squid.
(to the Waiter) Bring it on.
Yes sir. Anything to drink? » DOUG I’ll have a draft beer. Whatever goes best with squid. And bring my date here a glass of diet cyanide.

MONTAGE THEME AGAIN == ANTON at a VIDEO CAMERA, filming - DOUG and KATE as they skate. This. is getting more comple DOUG. lifting her on the move -- his hands all over her b turning -- landing her awkwardly and -- WIPE To: INT. . ANTON’S APARTMENT -- DAY DOUG at the table, staring as MARTIN sets a huge Thanksgi feast before him. ANTON enters from the kitchen, places a iced bottle of vodka and three shot glasses on the table.
What have we here?
We break training today. (to the Butler as he pours the shots) You are joining us, Martin? MARTIN looks up, interested. DOUG a little surprised.
(expansive) Of course you are. Thanksgiving is most special holiday for me.
Thanksgiving? In Russia?
No, I defect on Thanksgiving. Paris, November 27, 1974.
37 ANTON hands them shots. Raises his glass.
Let us drink to Pilgrims. The three men touch glasses and drink.
DOUG and ANTON staring out over Long Island Sound, passin a bottle of champagne, as the sun drops over the horizon.

».+-Z was very imaginative thinker. Big ideas. Dreams like cowboy western. America, I am sure, will be falling at my feet like drunk on sidewalk. (laughing at the memory) Here I am! -- I am coaching nine European Champions. I am coaching seven World Champions. Four gold Olympics. I am Burt Lancaster! (a wistful pause) So I come. I wait. Where is Cadillac? Where is red carpet? Big ideas need much feeding. Soon is no more Burt Lancaster in mirror. DOUG reaches in his pocket, pulls a LARGE TURKEY DRUMSTIC takes a bite and hands it to ANTON.

¢’non, you’re telling me nobody was interested? “ANTON . I speak no English. I have no money. American coaches, powerful coaches, are not helping. I drink too much... (drifting into Russian) ...Beda ni prikhodit odna.
What’s that mean?
Bad shit never comes alone. (a bite of turkey) So I drive cab. I write letters. I master language of English. (he grins) I come here.  33
What’s he pay you to coach her? ANTON flashes a cagey smile. It’s too good to talk about.
So what do you do with it all?
I have daughter. In Leningrad. I send dollars through Hungary.
She’s a skater?
No. My daughter is nurse. DOUG nods. .A pause. ANTON watches him, suddenly serious.
You wonder how I leave family behind, yes?
It’s none of my business.

Was very @ifficult time for me. Selfish time. Much unpopularity for me in Russia. Much unhappiness. Is no excuse. Is explanation. (he’s choking up) I am sorry...Thanksgiving, my heart is close to the skin. DOUG nods, takes back the drumstick. They stare out over the water as the MONTAGE THEME COMES UP and <- cUT TO:
In the BG, A JANITOR drives a ZAMBONI around the ice. KAT and DOUG are seated on the sidelines. She’s reading. He’s impatiently taping up a hockey stick. KATE looks over.
If you’re so bored, why don’t you read?
What? You mean a book?
That is a traditionally accepted format, yes.
DOUG grunts. Continues with the stick.
Don’t you ever read?
Like what?
I don’t know, TV Guide?
Hey, look, I can read.
So what’s the last book you read? (he shrugs) You were in college.
The last thing I read in college was the letter cancelling my scholarship when I couldn’t play anymore.
You must’ve had to read a book in high school.
I was a hockey player. I’ve been. a hockey player since I was nine. The only thing a hockey player has to be able to read is the penalty clock.
And they graduated you?
Graduated me? They revered me. I was a God.
What a tragic commentary on our times.

State championships, my last game, grown men wept like children. Two hundred people carried me on their shoulders around the ice until the Minnesota State Police came to break it up. The ZAMBONI heads off the ice. 3g
So what were you planning on doing when your gladiating days were over?
You can bet your tights I never thought I’d be working in a freakshow like this.
(entering behind them) Children! On the ice please. KATE stands, pulls her skate guards, turns to DOUG.
I’m surprised you don’t just chuck it all and start your own think tank.
You‘’re pretty sure I don’t know what that means, aren’t you? KATE smiles. Skates away. DOUG stands there, hating her.
(under his breath) Bitch.
(she heard him) Boob. . cUT TO:
Snow on the ground. Christmas lights on evergreens.
‘INT. KATE’S LOCKER ROOM -- DAY KATE, half-dressed, is startled by a KNOCK AT THE DOOR --
-- You want to hang on please! DOUG comes through the door. KATE grabs frantically for a towel -- barely covering up as --

-- What the hell do you think you're -- Did I say come in? DOUG, holding a CRUDELY WRAPPED PACKAGE in his hands, sta his ground, enjoying KATE’s discomfort as she quickly kno the towel above her chest.
o- Get out! out this second! DOUG smiles, eyes all over her.
Kate, I handle the stuff all the time, it’s not that big a mystery. KATE stands there stiffly. Something challenged in her expression. A moment as she recovers her poise.
Merry Christmas. ‘ (offering the package) Think fast. He tosses the package -- she catches it, almost losing he towel. She stares at him, and then opens her locker, pui: out a DESIGNER-WRAPPED BOX.
(hurling it at him) Happy holiday. DOUG snags it before it takes off his head. KATE starts t open hers, DOUG watching. :
Pretty tough, shopping for the girl who has everything.
(looking down) Oh...
Actually, I didn’t have much time to shop. KATE holds a worn, vintage CHICAGO BLACKHAWKS JERSEY at arm’s length.
An old shirt...
irt? -- Bobby Hull wore that! Bobby Hull for chrissake -- I’ve had that shirt for fifteen years! (Kate stares) Forget it -- you don’t want it, I/1l take it back.
No, no -- I like it. Realiy.  KATE finds a smile. DOUG cools.
So open yours. DOUG starts on his gift -- pulling off the ribbon and the his expression sours -- A BOOK. .-
«.-"Great Expectations?"
(smiling) It was that or "Curious George Plays Hockey." I took a chance. CUT To:

DOUG, dressed: in an ill-fitting, brown polyester suit an black tie, stands with ANTON at the front door. THE DOOR swings open --: the FULL RUSH OF A LARGE PARTY. JACK MOSE stands there smiling in a tuxedo.
Happy New Year! C’mon in! cUuT TO:

DOUG and ANTON enter a big party, in the grand, upper cru tradition. Prosperous MEN AND WOMEN, in tuxedos and eveni gowns. BUTLERS and WAITERS circle with champagne and tray of food. A DANCE BAND plays from THE BALLROOM. DOUG stares around, amazed. This is exactly how the other half lives. And then his gaze settles on --

KATE gathered with a GROUP OF PEOPLE. She is resplendent; .devastating in a tight, .drop-dead, strapless.gown. We k she looked good, but we have never seen her like this. A tall, sandy-haired, TUXEDOED MAN in his late twenties, pu his arm around her waist, as the GROUP breaks into laught DOUG stands there, gaping. A passing BUTLER proffers a tray of champagne glasses. DOUG grabs one, drains it fast
PARTY SOUNDS (OS). DOUG at the mirror. Pulling at his hai Brushing his cheap suit. Tugging his tie. No improvement. He’s never felt more like a hick in his life.

42  43 INT. JACK’S STUDY/ TROPHY ROOM PARTY SOUNDS (OS). DOUG alone, in a corner, staring at a COLLECTION OF PHOTOGRAPHS distanced slightly from the res INSERT THE PHOTOS -- Black and whites, with a texture and atmosphere that dates them from the fifties. Featured in picture is a young woman skater, KATE’S MOTHER, in variou poses on the ice: Dancing -- Alone -- Surrounded by an Ic Capades-type chorus line. She is beautiful, glamorous; th glow of a powerfully unique personality shines through. DOUG steps away from this shrine, starts for the door, wh
(entering) ~~ Hale? (seeing Doug) Oh...
I was just looking --
Weren’t these doors closed?
Sort of, but... KATE moves aside; she wants him out. DOUG passes into --
as KATE closes the doors tightly behind them.
It’s not a museun. DOUG, about to apologize, realizes KATE is staring at his outfit.
(self-conscious) Black tie, I thought --
Yes, your tie jis black. DOUG stiffens, vulnerable, ready for her to lay him out.
(softening) Don’t worry about it.
Anton should’ve told me.
It’s not that big a deal. A WAITER passes with champagne. DOUG grabs two glasses, desperate to change the subject.
I was gonna tell you, that book you gave me, it’s something else.
(with a smile) Really? Are you using it as a door stop or a coaster?
(handing her a glass) . Very funny. .
I don’t drink.
Dou. ‘ | It’s only champagne.
I’ve never had a drink in my life.
i e . You’re kidding, right? (she stares back, definitely not kidding) What is it, the calories?
(bristling) Considering your knowledge of self contrel is about as extensive as your wardrobe, I’d hardly expect you to understand.
c’mon Kate, everybody’s got to cut loose sometime. It’s New Years Eve for chrissake -- one glass...
As thrilling as this moment may be for you, it’s hardly what I would describe as transformational. THE MAN we saw with Kate on the stairs steps INTO FRAME.
. Kate, there you are....
ur THE MAN leans in -- suddenly aware of DOUG’s presence.
Hale, this is Doug. Doug Dorsey, Hale Forrestal. HALE is instantly focused. A quick patrician smile.
Well, finally...The Secret Weapon. I’ve heard so much about you. HALE offers his hand, DOUG stuck with the two glasses, no
May I? (plucking one) This calls for a toast. DOUG chafes under HALE’s inspection.
Let’s drink to the little people. HALE blinks as DOUG drains his glass. KATE watches them.
I understand you were at the University of Minnesota.
For a while.
I played a little hockey myself. For fun. :
(flatly) Yeah? Let me know sometime, we’1l slap it around.
If you two will excuse me, naked male insecurity really leaves me cold. KATE walks. HALE and DOUG left staring after her. HALE, recovering his swagger, turns back to DOUG.
So, dude, back for long? A pause. HALE regards DOUG unpleasantly.
aay oO
Just several days. We/ve been very busy in the London office. But then I gather you’ve been on quite a schedule as well. Douc Jack. likes to get his money’s worth.
I understand you've been giving Kate a rough time of it.
You know Kate.
Yes, I do. For quite a while. And I don’t like to see her upset.
I was you, I’d invest in blindfolds. Before HALE can find his tongue, DOUG is walking away.
THE BALLROOM.: THE BAND really playing. On the dance floo ANTON tearing it up with a very spry DOWAGER.

KATE stands near a buffet table with several SOCIALITES. As THEY BANTER, KATE’S eyes drift across the room -~ her expression souring as she watches -- DOUG -- ACROSS THE ROOM -- standing with TWO 18-YEAR-OLD DEBUTANTES. We can’t hear what he’s saying from this far away, but whatever it is, the DEBS are loving it; gigglin and flirting like crazy.
THE CROWD gathered in the BALLROOM. THE BANDLEADER counti down the final seconds of 1991 --
...ten...nine... (the crowd joining in) +..-eight...seven... IN THE BACK OF THE ROOM -- DOUG alone in the doorway.
an THE CROWD -+.Six...five... A FEW YARDS AWAY -- KATE reaches down to manuever HALE’s hand off her ass. .
...four...three...two...one...

HORNS -~- CONFETTI -- "AULD LANG SYNE" == COUPLES embrace DOUG is grabbed by ONE OF THE DEBUTANTES for a big kiss, and then he’s passed to THE SECOND DEBUTANTE, another kis and then he’s handed over to AN OLDER WOMAN and -- SEVERAL YARDS OFF <= KATE pulled from HALE’s embrace into arms of AN OLDER MAN and then passed to ANOTHER MAN and t MUSIC’S GOING and COUPLES all over the room are doing the thing and KATE is surrendering to the moment when suddenl

thrust into each other’s arms, instinctively moving towar a kiss -- when suddenly THEY FREEZE. A dead stop. KATE recoils. DOUG stiffens. And then, pretending it never happened, they turn away into the crowd.
MUSIC echoing from the ballroom. DOUG enters, grabs a BOTTLE OF CHAMPAGNE from an ice bucket and keeps on going

INT. KATE’S BEDROOM -- LATER Dark. Kate’s gown crumpled in a mess on the floor. Hale’s tuxedo folded carefully over a chair. IN BED'-- HALE asleep and snoring. KATE, beside him, is w awake, looking tense and unsatisfied. She stands, pulling sheet around her, moving across the room to THE WINDOW. She listens, then THROWS THE WINDOW OPEN and stares out. The FAINT SOUND OF ROCK AND ROLL playing from somewhere.

head_text.subj: POUNDING ROCK AND ROLL ECHOES THROUGH THE BUILDING. DOUG,

text: alone, on the ice. Hockey stick in hand. Dozens of pucks littered around the ice. A private moment of total free-f mania. DOUG skating, blitzing -- firing pucks against the wall like a man possesed; like a man who has no choice bu burn off his reckless energy before it kills him.
48 DISSOLVE To:
ANTON stands at the front door, talking with KATE.
What do you mean, we’re taking the weekend off?
Just till Monday. Is three days. He works very hard. We make much progress. (she’s waiting for details) Steam is needing to be blown off. You know...outside contact....
When you say outside contact what exactly are we talking about?

Katya, please, is not boy. Is man. Young vigorous man. (he tries a smile) Too much...solitude is not good. . e@ KATE ue We work seven days a week. We work Thanksgiving. We work Christmas. I have the flu, and we work. I have a boyfriend in London, and we work. I show up every day of the week and skate a remedial pairs clinic so you can play Dr. Frankenstein with this goon! I show up ready to work every day for nineteen weeks and now you give him two days off so he can go ‘whoring around New York?
: Is not entirely correct. (Kate stares) He went to Boston. - As THE DOOR SLAMS SHUT in his face.

TWO PAIRS OF SKATES -- both in mid-air, SLICE INTO FRAME. SUPER-SLOW MOTION as they turn, glistening above the ice. . Touching down, the SLOW MOTION ACCELERATES -- MUSIC FAD Vo. IN -- THE CAMERA BEGINS TO PULL AWAY -- SUPERIMPOSE:

KATE AND DOUG IN THE DOME -- skating the hell out of a re routine. ‘ They’ve gotten very good -- arabesque into a d toe loop throw -- KATE in the air -- landing in DOUG’s ar and into the big finish as THE MUSIC PEAKS -- a side-by-s blur spin at center ice as THE NUMBER ENDS.
HOUSEKEEPERS all applauding. KATE AND DOUG -- rise from their finishing positions. The nuclear winter of their past relationship has warmed over time into a grudging respect.
You’re still rushing the Lutz.
Maybe you just ought to go with it. (Kate looks over, Doug smiles) Do what I do -- just close your eyes and commit. KATE is about to rebut, as JACK and ANTON bound onto the
Just tremendous! Tremendous! HALE, in loafers, slips and slides awkwardly toward thes
Honey, you were terrific! THEY ALL turn as HALE falls on his ass onto the ice.

A WAITER standing-by and FINALLY TO -- DOUG transformed -- at least partially: A well-tailored « Tanned and fit. Long hair pulled back stylishly. Hardiy the oafish rube we remember from New Year’s Eve party.
I’1l have the terrine of seafood, followed by the steak au poivre, and I’d like that rare please. The WAITER nods, backs away. JACK leans into the table
Let’s get down to business. It’s Labor Day weekend, where do we stand?
First is to get Douglas eligible.
What’s that going to be like?
For you is like test pilot taking driver’s exam.
And then into the sectionals?

We skip sectionals. They turn -- this is news -- ANTON pulls a book from his bag, places it on the table. ANTON . USFSA rule number eight-hundred and twenty-three... (he opens the book begins to read--) "Former World Team Pairs members competing with eligible partners may receive, upon application to the Executive Council, a bye into the National Championships."
Straight to the nationals?
I love it.
You’re kidding.
Rule is rule. Who expects former champion to skate with unknown. (he closes the book) January five. New Orleans.
And then the Olympics in February. (he grins) I smell gold... The table brims with confidence. Only ANTON dissents.
Hopes perhaps must be scaled back.
What’re you talking about?

Figure skating is not like hockey. Team scoring most goals does not always win. This is yery small world. People will not be rushing to welcome us. (looking around) I am outsider. Douglas is freak. Katya...well... (he lets this go) Let’s just say we are having three strikes against us. To be winning place on team we will have to be best by very much.
So we’ll be the best.
(raising his glass) To success. ,
Hell, we can do better than that. (Hale stops--) I say we kick some butt.
That’s the ticket! -- Let’s drink to kicking butt. THEY clink glasses and sip -- KATE drinking soda.

I have another announcement to make. (he looks at Kate) . Jack’s seen fit to transfer me back to the home office in New York, and Kate and I... (he hesitates) «.ewell, we’re going to be married this winter,
(correcting him) I told you -- the Spring. After competition.
Spring, winter, whatever.

52 JACK and ANTON break huge grins. HALE, beaming, puts his arm around KATE’s shoulder, CLOSE-UP -- DOUG -- as this news registers. He’s stunned, and more than that, he’s stunned that he’s stunned. WE HO ON HIM for this next:
Oh Katie...it’s about time! I was wondering how long I’d have to wait!
This becomes quite the night, Katya, please, my kiss. DOUG rallies, summons a hearty smile.
Congratulations. That’s great.
Show them the ring, Kate.
My God...Now that’s a piece of ice. STILL ON DOUG -- as the conversation DRIFTS AWAY away and curT To:

Brightly lit and practically deserted. On the ice, a ten-year-old GIRL skates to the final chorus of "TOMORROW She almost falls, recovers, and it’s over. OFF THE ICE -- THREE TEST JUDGES sit at a desk marked: USFSA TESTING. The JUDGES check off their scores and nod approvingly at the GIRL, who nervously exits the ice.
(calling around the rink) Male senior pairs test. Skaters twelve and thirteen, please.
KATE AND DOUG wearing plain, elegant warm-up suits, emerg ANTON in the shadows behind then.
The JUDGES and a SMALL GROUP of YOUNG SKATERS, PARENTS, a COACHES gathered behind them, react with amazement:
--Mommy, that’s Kate Moseley! ~-It’s Kate Moseley! --Couldn’t be... --My God, it is... KATE AND DOUG skate to center ice, as the GROUP falls sil
(very surprised) Kate, well... Nice to see you back.
It’s nice to be here.

Whenever you're ready. A beat. AND THEN MUSIC -- something simple and orchestral -- begins to PLAY -- and KATE AND DOUG begin to skate. THE JUDGES look blown away. THE GROUP OF SKATERS AND PARENTS watch in awe. This is something special and they know it. cUuT TO: INT. DOUG’S APARTMENT -- NIGHT The place is a mess, but a mess with a new slant -- BOOKS littered all over -- SKATING TAPES stacked by the VCR. DOUG is sprawled on the couch, reading. A KNOCK AT THE DO
Who is it?

(through the door) It’s me. Kate. DOUG reacts, this is very unusual. He jumps off the couch glancing around the room, gauging the epic proportion of mess, but before he can jump into action -- KATE, dressed to go out, pushes her way in.
Kate... She stands there a moment, looking around curiously, as i this were the first time she’d been here.
I came to say have a good trip. You’re leaving in the morning.
Yeah.
I brought the tape. Last practice. uo i She lays the tape on the table, eyes moving around the ro
I haven’t been up here in a long time. Not since Brian. DOUG watches her as she gives the place a real inspecticn
It’s a little different.
Brian had mirrors up all over. DOUG . Yeah, I took ‘em down. ~ {off balance) It’s kind of a mess, I wasn’t --
(surprised) Books...
Gotta pass the time, right? KATE stops at a Playboy centerfold pinned to the wall.
I guess when you’re not reading... {still snooping she stops at--)

head_text.subj: A DOZEN FRAMED PHOTOS OF THE 1988. OLYMPIC HOCK

text: TEAM -- featured prominently on the wall.
(staring at the collection) Ahhh...The Wall Of Shame.
Laugh if you want. I look at it, it keeps me going..
Is that what keeps you going?
Everybody’s got something behind then.
vw uw KATE glances back.
It’s not like I’m the only one who’s got memories on the wall. KATE digests this. Turns back to the pictures. DOUG laughs. She stares as
Bet you can’t pick out the best looking guy on the team.
The one with the mask.
What keeps you going, Kate? (she turns) Do you really like to skate? if ‘she'd never considered this question before.

It’s just, sometimes -- well a lot of the time, actually, it doesn’t seem like you're getting off on the stuff -- I mean, you’re great. You work like crazy. You skate the shit out of everything, but --
(calling from below) Kate? -- You coming?
(calling down) Be right there! (back to Doug) I’ve been skating for a very long time. People expect me to skate well. It’s what I do, it’s --
That’s not what I mean.
(she laughs) What is this? -- I stop up to say have a nice weekend and you’re going to start giving me training tips?
I only asked if you liked to skate.
ue ov
Everybody can’t just "close their eyes," and throw themselves off the cliff.
Open or closed, doesn’t make any difference, just as long as you jump. A pause, before --
Honey, we’re running late!
(answering sharply) I’1ll get there when I get there! She turns back to DOUG, shaking her head. A beat.
Going out?
Just a movie. They stand there a moment, KATE lingering.

You might want to check out the tape, your release into that twist Axel looks a little hesitant. (ribbing him) Wouldn't want to look uptight out there, would we? DOUG catches her eye, they stand there for a moment, but enough of a moment to scare her. She starts to back away ‘KATE Well...see you Monday, I guess.
You’re gonna miss me... KATE smiles, eyes sparkling for just an instant.

I’ll struggle through. And she’s gone. DOUG stands there a moment. He moves to ‘ the window, pulls the shade, stares down. DOUG’S POV -- THROUGH THE WINDOW as KATE and HALE get into a chauffeured car and pull away
vu cuT To: EXT. DORSEY’S PENALTY BOX -~ NIGHT The parking lot is jammed. MUSIC BLASTING from inside. CUT To:

"WELCOME HOME Doug" PULL BACK TO REVEAL -- THE BAR. The place is rocking. This is clearly the place to be in Mahorn, Minnesota tonight. No sign of DOUG or WALTER however. BLONDIE, 25, cute, in a ripe, blowzy way, wearing a halte top that does little to hide her ample charms, moves thro the crowd, balancing a pitcher of beer and two glasses --
(over the music)
(heads shake no, she moves on) —_— i ? (Mikey shrugs, she’s getting pissed) Where is that sonofabitch?
DOUG and WALTER outside, alone, standing amidst empty keg and garbage. The TRAILER in the BG.
(incredulous) -- Eigure skating? Are you kidding me, or what? -- Figure skating? DOUG cringes, motions for WALTER to be quiet --
Don’t shush me! ~- Jesus Christ, Dougie, I just spent the last eleven months telling everybody and their brother that you were off in the goddamned Merchant Marines!
I just didn’t know how to tell you. WALTER stares at him as if he were a total stranger.
...Figure skating. Jesus...
You know how we always talked about the new bar, the place in town -- I’m serious, this time next year, you could be picking out chandeliers --
-- Gimme a break already! Forget about the new goddamned bar. I have.
Walter, I swear -- I could go all the way.

All the way to where? I mean, come on Doug -- you’re a hockey player for crying out loud. If you’re lucky -- if you’re yery lucky -- this time next year, you'll be inside a Snoopy costume, skating in the frigging Ice Capades.
I’m telling you, I’m good.
This is figure skating. You been : @ gone a year. How good could you be?

You know me better than that! I’m telling you I’m good and you better believe me. And you better believe I’m not working fifteen hours a day every day of the week to win some consolation prize. Christ, Walt, do you know what an Olympic gold medal is worth? -- We’re talking everything from Wheaties boxes to snow tires!
What about the girl? She as crazy as you. are?
In her own way. WALTER looks at his little brother. Shrugs. Smiles.
(gesturing the bar) Let me break it to ’em slowly. / On that -- THE BACK DOOR OPENS -- BLONDIE stands there beaming a big lascivious grin at DOUG.
or o
You can run, but you can’t hide. DOUG swallows. He’d like to do both.
EST. SHOT -- SEVENTH AVENUE. The garment district.
TWO MANNEQUINS -- dressed in a matching pair of wildly-cu sequined skating outfits. DOUG, ANTON, KATE and a CLOTHIN DESIGNER, a woman of 40, stare at these creations --
Hey, if this is a joke, I’m ready to laugh... The DESIGNER pales. KATE stares at him. ANTON braces.
Look, if anybody here thinks I’m getting inside one of those things they better guess again.
Marcia and I, quite honestly, we thought it would look good on you.
Something sheer and well... {admiring DOUG’s physique) You don’t want to hide your light under a basket.
Oh great. So now we’re hawking my ass out there?
Deo you know how long we’ve worked on this?
Do I care?
Marsha designs for all the top pairs. She’s always done my outfits.
(sarcastically) Oh well, that changes everything.
Two CD PLAYERS side by side -- WE HEAR (QVER) A CHAOTIC MIX OF MUSIC: a lush SYMPHONY of romantic strings competi with the hard crunching beat of some serious ROCK AND ROL

head_text.subj: THE CAMERA TRACKS ALONG THE TWO SETS OF HEADPHONE WIRES -

text: KATE’S BEDROOM -- THE MANSION Large and luxurious. A pink, feminine, almost saccarine decor. Everything in it’s place, except for the floor tha is covered with CDs -- hundreds of them scattered everywh

both wearing headphones, sprawled on the floor, listening It looks as though this has been a long session, DOUG is grimly sucking on a beer. KATE, turned away, does not loo Happy about what she’s listening to either. KATE rips off her headphones -- the ROCK AND ROLL DISAPPEARS INSTANTLY THE TRACK.
(turning to Doug) You’ve got to be kidding. He can’t hear her. KATE leans to the stereo, shuts the power. THE CLASSICAL MUSIC STOPS -- silence.
(pulling off his phones) -- What?
I said: You’ve got to be kidding.
You didn’t like it? -- That’s one of ny favorite tunes.
(reprising his earlier costume complaint) "on, well, that changes everything."
Come on... You got off on it and you’re afraid to tell me.
KATE stands. She stares as
Dream on. But what about the Chopin? I should never have interrupted you, you looked mesmerized.
I was falling asleep. Starts gathering her CDs in a huff.
Kate, look, ten thousand other skaters are gonna be cueing up the same boring crap.
Chopin, for your information, is hardly easy-listening.
c'mon, it’s like the costumes, I mean, let’s break a little ground. Let’s kick a little ass.

I keep telling you -- judges don’t like to be shocked. They don’t even like music with vocals. You throw on a pair of jeans and try skating to this stuff and the only asses in line to be kicked will be ours!

You really think we can win any other way? Because I think Anton's right -- I think we’re a freakshow. I think we've gotta blow them away because they’re never gonna let us brown-nose our way into a medal.
You want to win, you play it straight.
(with a smile) Didn’t work for you before. DOUG pulls one last CD from his pocket.
What’s that?
(moving for the stereo) I been saving this for last.
I think I’ve had enough. Let’s just call it a night. DOUG pops in the CD, punches it up. A DRUM BEAT FILLS THE ROOM -- IT’S LOUD --'A SYNTH BASS THUMPS IN --
Doug! .
(offering his beer) Have a sip. We’re gonna dance.

We are not. DOUG puts down the beer and kicks away the other CDs as THE MUSIC COMES ALIVE. There’s a lot of music in this fil but this is The Song -- our hit single, and whatever else may be it’s definitely contemporary, urgent, and sexually romantic. As THE MUSIC BUILDS, DOUG reaches for KATE’s ha She pulls away. DOUG decides to go it alone --

(moving through it) Okay...into the layback...one, two three, four...and out -- a little serpentine bullshit across the ice and then double axel twist lift... and whoaa...looking good, check her out...what an arch...and this guy’s not too shabby either, letting her down soocco easy -- THE CAMERA FEATURES -- KATE, starting to smile, swaying slightly to the music, as DOUG “skates" around the room. She’s can’t help getting caught up in his enthusiastic vi

-- rounding the far turn, picking up a little speed here -- she’s smiling, she knows this is happening -- this guy isn’t just good, he’s incredible -- outside edges, and she picks and -- gimme a break, nobody nails a camel spin like this -- Talk about poetry in motion -- Suddenly THE MUSIC STOPS -- DOUG caught in mid-move -- HALE, standing there, in robe and pajamas, half asleep.
Guys, it’s midnight. I’ve got a six-thirty appointment.
We were just wrapping up. HALE stares at KATE as DOUG grabs his coat and beer.
{to Kate as he goes) Think about it.
KATE alone on the ice, practices a spin. She comes out of it and something catches her eye -- she stares. OFF THE ICE -- RICK TUTTLE stands there watching her.
You're still dropping your shoulder on the exit. _ KATE, shocked, skates closer for a better look.
We had an exhibition up in Hartford. I was ariving past. (looking around) . They remembered me at the gate.
What are you doing here?
I thought you’d retired.
I changed my mind.

I heard. You know what I think is the saddest thing about sports: people who stay too long at the party. (he smiles) You were a great champion, Kate. We had a nice run. Maybe it ended badly, but I blame myself for that.
What are you doing here, Rick?
I’m saying I’d like to see you go out a champion.
That’s the plan.  64
If you’d wanted to skate that badly, why didn’t you come to me? I know we made some mistakes but --
? You spent ten years tying me into knots!
You were always difficult.

Is that how you tell it, Rick? Because I remember it differently. I remember a nine-year-old girl who was willing to do anything to keep people happy. And for Rick Tuttle, my God... (she laughs) I skated through fire for you. I turned myself inside out trying to please you, and it was never, ever enough, was it?
I’m sorry you feel that way. You meant a lot to this sport. You still do. (he pauses, shrugs) I’d just hate to see you humiliated. KATE stands there, defiance instantly replaced by doupt.
Humiliated?
(sensing blood) Come on, Kate, this guy, a hockey player... : (he smiles) I mean, let’s face it, trusting partners has never been your strong suit. KATE takes a deep breath, willing herself calm.

Just so you know, before you get the hell out of my building -- this guy, this hockey player, is the best skater I’ve ever been on the ice with. He’s going to make you cry he’s so good.  on ui TUTTLE says nothing. A moment.

You know your way out. TUTTLE nods, turns, and walks back and out the way he cam KATE stands there, flushed. She skates to the runway, lifts a bottle of water to her lips and stops cold -- THERE’S DOUG -- slouched in the shadows. He’s heard the whole thing. He stands, starts slowly for the ice. KATE ‘ (she means it) You let me down, I swear to God, I’ll knock out what’s left of your teeth.

(as he nears) Don’t sweat it, Kate. (pointing to his ring finger) Do me one favor, willya? Take off the rock while we work. It’s cutting the hell out of my hand. She can only stare as he pulls his guards and hits the ic
KATE and HALE eating dinner, as she studies a videotape o practice. A pause before --
I looked at that apartment today.
(rewinding the tape) I keep telling him he’s got to get more extension on that Lutz.
Did you hear me? (Kate turns) The place in New York. East seventy sixth. I went with the broker.
You. went without me?
It’s not going to stay on the market forever.
HALE leans closer, takes her hands.
Why don’t you take off tomorrow? Come in, we’ll have lunch, we can look at it together.
Tomorrow? It’s just that... HALE shakes his head, looks down -- pales --
Kate...the ring -- Where’s the ring?

(fumbling) I, I took it off -- for practice -- it’s in my bag, my skate bag... HALE nods, swallowing his displeasure. ‘KATE tries to smi In the BG, the PRACTICE TAPE finishes rewinding and START TO PLAY AGAIN. . cuT To:
Transformed into competition headquarters. VIDEO and COMPUTER EQUIPMENT strewn all over. DOUG, ANTON, and a COMPUTER TECHNICIAN move aside, ushering KATE to the seat directly in front of the monitor.

(to the Technician) Please to show her... INSERT -- THE MONITOR -- FULL FRAME -- A sports imaging program -- The TECHNICIAN TAPS on the KEYBOARD -- and the screen comes alive ~- green pixel silhouettes of KATE and DOUG begin moving across the ice -- and then explosion as KATE’s silhouette leaves the ice in slow-motion high into the air -- around...and around...and around and into the arms of DOUG‘s silhouette -- KATE sits back from the computer. Stares at them all.
I thought we’d call it a Pamchenko, but Anton’s not into it, so it’s a slingshot triple.
Key is centrifigal explosion of body from outside pick -- Is very exciting, yes? Cutting edge of man and machine?
67 KATE looks pale. She stares at them. They’re not kidding.
(betrayed) . This is what you’ve been doing? (the men stare) No one does a three and half! Nobody even thinks about it!
That’s the whole point. Kate, this could be unreal -- Your outside edge, my strength -~-
-- and I’m the one who falls! DOUG .. I’ll be right there.
(to Anton) My God, the Nationals are two weeks away!
(a sly smile) Maybe is not for Nationals. “KATE Maybe is not for me! . cuT To:
MUSIC PLAYING THROUGH THE DOME. ANTON choreographing, skating beside KATE and DOUG, urging them on, as they practice a balletic move in the progran.
MUSIC AGAIN. KATE and DOUG skating. ANTON trailing then, barking out corrections as they go. There’s an impatience to this -- time is running out.

INT. DOUG’S BEDROOM -- NIGHT A suitcase on the bed. DOUG, alone, packing. He folds in a pair of pants. Stops. Moves to the window. Stands there DOUG'S POV -- The mansion in the distance. A light shinin from Kate’s bedroom.
INT. KATE’S BEDROOM -- SAME TIME Four suitcases on the bed. KATE at her window. KATE’S POV -- Doug’s cottage in the distance.
EST. SHOT -- a building. Snow falling. Lights on inside.

head_text.subj: UNITED STATES FIGURE SKATING ASSOCIATION HEADQUARTERS

text: START ON -- A DESK NAMEPLATE: =: Vv: DIRECTOR USFSA as WE HEAR:

...Unorthodox isn’t the word! It’s an outrage! An affront to every - hardworking amateur skater in this organization! GERALD THUMAN, 50, distinguished, stares across his desk RICK TUTTLE. TWO OTHER SKATING OFFICIALS look on.

But, Rick....Kate’s a former Olympian, the rule may not be -= TUTTLE . -- When the Jack Moseley’s of this world are able to bring in Russian, mercenary coaches, put skaters on , and twist the language of gur bylaws to sneak a team into national competition, then I say maybe the system needs some looking into! OFFICIAL #1, a bearded man glances at TUTTLE before --
Rick may have a point here, Gerald. THUMAN looks nervously around the table. cuT TO:
A LIMOUSINE is parked out front. KATE, DOUG, and HALE are standing by the front door, BAGS stacked all around thea.
Where’s the make-up case?  69
Isn’/t it here?
No, Hale -- it’s not here!
I...I don’t know --
Fine! 1/11 do everything myself! She storms back into the house. HALE stares after her. DOUG watches all this with an air of detached amusement.

She’s very tense. (Doug nods) It’s understandable. The pressure is enormous. (Doug nods again) Her drive for perfection, it’s something I’ve come to admire. (he hesitates, measuring Doug before--) You seem to have mastered a sort of, I don’t know, a technique for @ handling her, I wondered if... . ‘ (this is difficult) «-.It’s just that, if this were a business situation, for example, and I knew that my dividends were shrinking and my assets were, let’s say, undervalued, and my market strategy was cratering despite my best efforts, I’d probably think about bringing on a consultant of some kind. You know, shake up my thinking. New perspective.
I’d suggest a more aggressive, take-charge approach.
You mean, standing up to her?
I’d try making it to my knees first, but that’s the right idea.
Hale! I’m in no mood to search “ this house!
Maybe I should start small and --
Hale? 2
Small may not cut it.
Timing is so important.
Yeah, timing’s a bitch.
Coming! HALE shoots DOUG a sheepish look as he rushes inside. CcuT TO:

KATE and ANTON walking a corridor. The arena is open for practice. SKATERS, COACHES, OFFICIALS milling around, as KATE and ANTON arrive at the USFSA RECEPTION DESK. A WOMA behind the desk, looks up, sees them and pales.
(very nervous) Kate Moseley?
Yes.
Didn’t? -- Hasn’t? -- Haven’t you been to the hotel?
We come straight here.

DOUG stopped at the RUNWAY, staring into THE ARENA. Thirt thousand empty seats. DOUG swallows. The enormity of the situation dawning on him as he looks out onto the ice he’ be skating on. He turns to see --
KATE, as mad as we’ve ever seen her, storming back up the hall toward him.
What’s going on? (no answer) Kate, what’s the matter?
They won’t let us skate!
JACK and SIX NEW YORK LAWYERS are seated across from THUM TUTTLE, and SEVERAL USFSA OFFICIALS. The mood is tense.

..-Rick’s raised some serious v4 allegations about Dorsey’s amateur status. I know you’ve flown your people down, Jack, but I’m doubtful we can clarify this in the next ten hours. ‘ The HEAD LAWYER is about speak, when JACK waves him off -
There isn’t a skater. in this hotel who doesn’t have a blind trust, club sponsor, or --
-- That’s absurd!

Since Mr. Tuttle seems incredulous, I think we owe him the courtesy of enlightenment, and to make it easy, I suggest we start by exploring the unique "scholarship" arrangement his skaters receive at the University where he so nobly acts as a tenured professor of... (drawing a blank) What is it exactly, Rick that you’re a professor of?
This is outrageous!
My feelings exactly.
-- Gentlemen, please!

Let’s cut to the cherry, Gerald. You cheat my kids out of their chance to skate and I’1l bury your butts so deep in legal compost it’1ll take a fucking millenium to dig your way out. Is that clear enough?

No crowd. On the ice, FOUR PAIRS, in warm ups, practicing COACHES, JUDGES, and OTHER SKATERS clustered in groups. . TUTTLE is huddled with his two skaters: BRIAN NEWMAN, Kat old partner, and LORIE PAULSEN, young, dark, and very cut
Ice is good? TUTTLE stiffens, turns, his eyes narrowing on -- ANTON smiling, as KATE and DOUG pass through the runway.
Practice. KATE AND DOUG on the ice. She’s leading him slowly. SKATERS all around them. DOUG looks tentative.
Nervous?
Me? -- Are you kidding? A PAIR skates past -- DOUG, having trouble seeing, picks them up almost too late. KATE pulls him back.
Don’t worry, it’s a head game. TWO.SKATERS COME SPEEDING PAST -- DOUG flinches.
Yumez and Weaver. They cry on command. ANOTHER PAIR -- TWINS -~- almost identical, come twirling by; huge idiotic smiles plastered across their faces.
The Weiderman twins. Don’t get too close, you’ll go into sugar shock. A THIRD PAIR stops with a flourish nearby.
Spindler and Nyman. He’s good, but she has one more doughnut and he’1ll never get her off the ice. SPINDLER, the male partner, looks over.
(very gay) Well, Kate, surprise surprise...
Hello, Gary.
(eyeing Doug) No wonder you’ve been keeping him to yourself. DOUG stares, very uncomfortable. SPINDLER winks before NYMAN, his hefty female partner pulls him away.
Jesus...

You’1l get used to it. DOUG looks unsure. They pick up the pace a little, still just getting loose. DOUG’s eye drawn away toward -- BRIAN AND LORIE PAULSEN on the ice, nearby. BRIAN lifting her and out into a finishing move. , :
Who’s that? KATE bristles, nudging him away.
Brian Newman, my old partner.
(still looking) And Paulsen, right? -- Lorie Paulsen. KATE looks at him, surprised. DOUG smiles.
Hey, just trying to keep up. CUT To: INT. MEN’S LOCKER ROOM A tight space. A DOZEN MALE SKATERS changing, showering. SPINDLER and BRIAN in the midst of a catty conversation:  © “1 a
I said, honey, if you think this is a workout, you’ve got’a lot to learn.
He can be such a Queen. DOUG, stripped to his underwear, stands nearby listening, tearing through his locker as fast as he can.

Give me a set of eyelashes like that and I’d get away with murder too. DOUG, in his haste, pulls too hard and the contents of h: locker come suddenly spilling out onto the floor. BRIAN and SPINDLER turn. DOUG, looking very uncomfortable grabs his jeans, and then stands to see them both eyeing
What? (Spindler and Brian exchange a coy glance) What’re you looking at?
Relax, honey. No one’s gonna steal your socks. DOUG, undone, turns away, yanking on his jeans.
ANTON seated, making notes, looks up to see DOUG rushing
Douglas! (Doug stops, Anton walks over) Katya is ready?
I’m going ahead.
(sensing trouble) Something is wrong?
Look, I’1l see you back at the hotel, okay?
Competition is so frightening?
ue
Hey, it’s not the skating. (Anton waits) Look, man, I’ve got a reputation to preserve. I’ve gotta live with myself. (he shakes his head) I should’ve known this was gonna be the story.
What story? What is problem?

I’ve been in a lot of locker rooms in my life and I’ve never, I mean, never, seen anything like that. (a beat) Half those guys are wearing make-up for chissake! ANTON stares. The message coming through loud and clear.
Is this a problem?
Is.this a problem? You think I want everyone going around saying I’m some kind of faggot? DOUG is angry. ANTON’s eyes narrow.
I should’ve known this would happen! You should’ve known. Christ, you’ve been in this racket for years, how the hell can you stand it?
Is simple. I am faggot. DOUG stares, ashen. ANTON’s expression unyielding.
Is true. Anton is homosexual.
«--but your daughter?
She is not gay.
That’s not what I mean! And what about Judy? Judy who’s calling all the time?
A friend. Her brother and I were once lovers.
C’mon -=- You were married! You had kids! -- (backing away) Oh man...we’ve been sharing that house for over a year! You...you should’ve told me -- I had every right to know!
Why? You are gay too?
No!
Then where is problem?
You could be trying to convert me!
Are you trying to be sleeping with with every woman you meet? (a beat) . Is bad question. Not everyone is so hungry. DOUG stands there, rocked. ANTON’s expression darkens.
I’m sorry for disappointment. We catch up later. You will excuse me. ANTON turns sharply and strides away.
INT. DOUG’S HOTEL ROOM -- DAY DOUG, alone in bed, staring at the ceiling. Fitful, thinking. Finally, he stands. cuT TO:
" poUG heading away from his room, rounding a corner to - AN ELEVATOR BANK -- LORIE PAULSEN standing there. She loo ever. Just the two of them. She smiles. Very friendly.
Going down?
You talked me into it. (he pauses) so, what'd you think of the ice?
Cold, flat and hard -- just like always. She smiles, watching him. DOUG a little off stride, as th EMPTY ELEVATOR opens. He holds the door.
(as she steps in) Just making small talk, or are you one of these monomaniacal skate-junkies? She’s got his attention. DOUG shakes his head, following her into the ELEVATOR as the DOOR CLOSES

Opening. Inside, DOUG and LORIE laughing so hard they fai to notice they’ve arrived at the lobby. DOUG looks up -- KATE AND HALE standing there. KATE venomously notes the scene. LORIE slips past, flashing a smile at KATE.
(to Doug) See you around,
Yeah. LORIE disappears into the lobby. HALE holds the door.
(icily) I thought you were napping.
I couldn’t sleep.
Anton went for the draw.
I/11 wait down here. HALE ushers KATE onto the elevator. She glares at DOUG as the DOORS CLOSE’. cuT TO:
INT. KATE’S HOTEL ROOM -= DAY KATE tearing furiously around the room. HALE watching.
Flirting around with that little slut! My God, he has the self control of a rabbit!
Kate, c’mon, it’s no big deal.

? Have you lost your mind? {Hale winces) God knows what he’s telling that little little tramp! HALE comes closer, begins massaging her shoulders. KATE s tensed-up that his overture doesn’t register at first.
I bet Brian put her up to it! HALE works his arms around her more amorously.
He’s an animal! Two minutes with that tart and he’s in heat! (noting Hale’s advances) What are you doing?
Taking your mind off it.
(pulling away) 2
Kate --
(wildly) -- He’s supposed to be in his room! He’s supposed to be sleeping! --
-> Kate --
(right over him) -- He’s supposed to be alone and resting and instead he’s downstairs, or God knows where, groping around with the biggest slut on the circuit! 73
You’re nuts!

-- Kate! (she stops) It’s a hotel for crying out loud! They were two people getting off an elevator! It’s hardly what I’d call a crisis. She’s gone too far. And she knows it. HALE stares at her, looking for something and not finding it.
This doesn’t have anything to do with skating, does it?
What do you mean?
You’re falling for him.
What?
You are. (as if it just hit him) You’re falling for him.
That’s crazy.
How far has it gone?
Am I? -~ How far has it gone?
You see how we act together.
I ‘sure do.
We’ve never gotten along! We’re always fighting!
Foreplay.
DoUG sitting reading a newspaper. He looks up to see --
) HALE huffing through the lobby, carrying his suitcase. This is aman in a hurry. He’s leaving. For good.
A limousine parked out front.
ANTON and DOUG waiting in silence. Tense silence, until:

Apologizing is like one of the worst things I do. I guess I never really picked it up. ANTON turns. DOUG, tight, hesitates. DOUG . What happened before...back at the dome...I wanted to tell you I was sorry. I made an ass of myself. ANTON . e@ As apologies go, that was acceptable.
I don’t want to get too good at it.
Life is not so simple, eh? pDoUG I guess not. A pause -- the moment broken as the DOOR OPENS and KATE barrels into the car. ANTON and DOUG stare at her, lookin for signs of breakage.
(definitively) I don’t want to talk about it. THE LIMO pulls out. KATE, sensing ANTON’s eyes still on her, wheels around, notes his concerned expression --
You want to worry about something? Worry about Ramjet the Rookie here! Nt ANTON glances over at DOUG.
Bi
You are okay?
Fine. No problem. Never better. CUT To:
The parking lot jammed. Crowds pouring into the building.
TWO ANNOUNCERS -- JOJO and. SCOTT -- talking to the CAMER
So here we are, Scott, night number four of the Nationals, the start of the Pairs Competition. scoTrT The country’s twelve best couples are in the building tonight and... (continuing as we--)
INT. MEN’S LOCKER ROOM ~-- SAME TIME SKATERS suiting up silently. DOUG off in the corner as --
«..only two of these couples are going to make the U.S. National Team and go on to the Olympics.
INT. _ LADIES’ LOCKER ROOM -- SAME TIME And if you thought the men’s dressing room was tense...

Tonight we’re seeing the short program, that is, the two and a half minute routine of required moves... KATE at the mirror, eyes wandering in the reflection TO F ~- LORIE PAULSEN at a mirror across the room smiling back
These skaters have drawn for position and the pairs with the highest scores after tonight will be seeded for tomorrow night’s long progran.
a2
The place packed. MUSIC PLAYING -- RACHMANINOFF -- as ONE OF THE TWELVE PAIRS skate their short program. Just a moment of this -- they turn, and a Camel sit spin and -
A GLENN MILLER CLASSIC -- ANOTHER PAIR -- into a lift and turn and they falter and SHE falls and --
A SOUSA MARCH PLAYING -- SPINDLER and NYMAN skating -- no bad, but he’s struggling a little to lift her and --
KATE and DOUG dressed in simple, elegant, flattering cost They’re on next. DOUG stands very stiffly. His eyes look unfocused. KATE watches him.
You look nervous. (no response) You look really ‘nervous. DOUG, stone~faced, says nothing. KATE moves closer.
How nervous are you? (Doug can’t talk)

A moment, and then suddenly -- DOUG dashes off -- sprinti several yards down the runway -- he stops -- leans under scaffolding of bleachers getting sick, as the SOUSA MARCH crashes to it’s rousing conclusion and the CROWD CHEERS. KATE is aghast. She looks around. SEVERAL SKATING MONITOR are staring at’ DOUG as he walks back gingerly.
What _is wrong with you?
(weakly) I always get tight before a game. KATE stares.at him. He’s hyperventilating.
Let’s put it this way, when I played hockey I used to have two helmets, the one I’d use during the game and the one I’d use before.
Why_hasn’t this come up before?
Bad choice of words. In the BG, SPINDLER AND NYMAN come flying off the ice.

(incredulous) . I don’t believe this! (Doug cringes as--) "Oh, I’m fine." "Never better." "No problem." “Don’t sweat it." DOUG looks woozy again. KATE is desperate. MORE PEOPLE standing around begin to take notice. She grabs hin.
Look at me! Look in my eyes. (she slaps him) Smile! DOUG tries a shaky smile. KATE grabs his ear, practically pulling it off -- DOUG howls --

Concentrate on my forehead! (yanking his ear) Look at me! -- Smile! -- Bigger! Breathe. ~ (she punches him) Breathe! (he does, Kate recoiling--) Ugh! -- Just don’t breathe on me. In the BG, THE CROWD REACTS to the SPINDLER-NYMAN scores.
Look, it goes away -- the worst I ever was, I went out and scored six goals in the first two periods.
(booming through the building) KATHERINE MOSELEY AND DOUG DORSEY.
What are you saying, as soon as we get. out there you’re gonna be fine?
It always just took me about ten minutes to relax. 33
Our program is two and half minutes! DOUG forces a smile. Takes her hand.
So eight minutes after we’re done I’ll be fine.

KATE AND DOUG first position. MUSIC SWELLS -=- something explosive and bold -- and they begin to skate. And we've never really seen them in action, and we’re not going to much of this, but what we do see is impressive before --
ANTON -- watching from the sidelines nervously. THE JUDGES -- scoring, faces impossible to read. JACK -- in the stands, beaming. They must be doing good.
JOJO and SCOTT wrapping up the night. ScoTT What a night for skating!

And the headline in New Orleans tonight is Kate Mosely returning to the Nationals with a new partner, ex-hockey player Doug Dorsey. scoTr _I/11 admit it, Jojo, when I heard about this couple I thought they had to be kidding, but Doug Dorsey -- Wow! I guess you’d have to say he’s the Bo Jackson of the skating world. There’s a lot of shocked people in this town tonight. oe . CUT To: INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR -- NIGHT . DOUG, ANTON and KATE exiting the ELEVATOR, skate bags ove their shoulders. THEY’RE LAUGHING, basking in the moment victory, wandering up the hallway as WE HEAR OVER:

Brian Neuman and Lorie Paulsen, no surprises there, take the number one spot. John and Jody Weiderman skate a very safe but proficient number two and Kate Mosely and Doug Dorsey come out of nowhere to grab the three spot. Amid "goodnights," ANTON breaks off -- his room in the ne wing. KATE and DOUG continue on, still laughing as:
But three into to two won’t go, and two couples is all the U.S. will be sending to the Olympics this year.
Tomorrow afternoon’s long program should be very exciting. V.O. FADES OUT -- KATE slows as they near her room.
..if they were giving french fries instead of trophies, then you’d see her air it out. DOUG laughs. KATE stops at her door.
See you tomorrow? ; * pouc I might be free. KATE shakes her head, finds her key. DOUG backing away.
Hey, Kate... (she turns) Thanks for getting me through it. KATE blinks. DOUG turns, walking away. She watches him go DISSOLVE To:
GROUPS OF SKATERS, COACHES and FAMILIES gathered outside waiting for-transportation. DOUG stands alone to one side
Good morning. He turns -- LORIE PAULSEN behind him. DOUG smiles.
Hey.
What, are you doing tonight?
I hadn’t thought about it.
Why don’t we meet after. (she smiles) We can compare bruises. On that, LORIE turns and walks away. DOUG watches her go.
LAP DISSOLVE A SERIES OF SCORES <= one to the next on the board, indicating the first three groups have skated.

The LAST FOUR PAIRS warming up on the ice. THE WEIDERMAN TWINS. SPINDLER and NYMAN. FINALLY TO -- KATE AND DOUG -- taking it easy as BRIAN an LORIE come whipping past. KATE turns, eyes boring a hole through LORIE, as a LOUD BUZZER echoes through the buildi

ANGLE THE ICE -- Nothing for a moment -- JUST MUSIC, THE FINAL CHORUS OF SOMETHING GOOD AND BALLSY -- and then sud KATE and DOUG heave INTO FRAME -- AND NOW WE’RE RIGHT WIT THEM -- THE CAMERA sweeping along, no one’s ever shot ice skating like this before -- hand in hand, they speed acro the ice -- THE MUSIC PEAKING -- an arabesque -- looking r good -- into a lasso lift throw -- swooping to a blisteri stop -- THE ROUTINE IS OVER -- THE CROWD EXPLODES and --
KATE, DOUG, and ANTON staring at the scoreboard as --
KATE stiffens. DOUG squints. ANTON looks displeased.
87 CUT To:
JOJO and SCOTT broadcasting.

It’s hard to explain sometimes to people outside the sport, but scoring can really reflect more than what’s happening out on the ice. scoTT The judges have their favorites, and this evening I’m not sure if Kate and Doug fall into that category.
I thought that was a super program, but with the top two seeded pairs still to skate, it looks like Kate and Doug are headed for third place.
DOUG and KATE alone. He’s raging -- storming around the hallway, absolutely furious. KATE looks ready to ery.
-- This is horseshit! What kind of crap are they trying to pull? -- We skated our asses off out there! KATE bites her lip, watching him rail around the hallway.
(wildly) : i ! -- I mean, am I crazy or did we just nail that goddamned program to the wall? He’s scaring her, she’s never seen him like this. SEVERAL PASSERSBY glance over nervously.
Doug, please...It’s not over yet.
(turning on her) Bullshit! -- We could’ve raised the roof off this building and they wouldn’t’ve placed us!

83 ‘THE ICE -- LATER BRIAN AND LORIE skating to BIZET’S CARMEN. They look good A big move -- they're really selling it and -- a WIPE TO: THE SCOREBOARD . Flashing numbers -- 5.9, 5.9, 6.0, 5.8, 5.9, 5.9, 5.8.

POLKA MUSIC fills the arena -- and here come the WEIDERMA TWINS, replete with leiderhosen and surreal smiles. Fancy toe-work across the ice -- and then he lifts her and they and -- SHE FALLS -- bad -- real bad -- THE CROWD GASPS -- cur To:
KATE brushing at tears. DOUG silently steaming, as the SOUND OF THE CROWD’S GASP overwhelms the POLKA MUSIC. KATE looks up to see -- ANTON sprinting from the runway, rushing toward them --
Doug...
(turning) What?

We gid it! OTHER SKATERS AND COACHES look: on as ANTON pulls KATE an DOUG into an ecstatic embrace. KATE transformed instantly bouncing around -- DOUG HOWLING -- KATE YELLING -- As THE celebrate, a SKATING OFFICIAL moves toward them.
Excuse me? -- Excuse me? (they turn, all smiles) We need to see the skaters alone. cuT TO:
A SIGN READING -- USFSA DRUG TESTING PROGRAM hangs from t wall. KATE, holding an empty plastic cup, stares balefull at A WOMAN OFFICIAL.
You’ll have to give me something.
I guess I’m just sort of worked up. The WOMAN moves to a cooler. Opens it. KATE looks in.
I have Coke, Sprite, Gatorade...
Is that a beer in there? The WOMAN pulls a Budweiser, hands it over. KATE pops the top, braces, and takes a sip. She smiles. She likes it.

Awards ceremony. TRIUMPHANT MUSIC booms through the arena as the top three pairs wave to the crowd. BRIAN AND LORIE standing on the top step. KATE AND DOUG right below in second. THE WEIDERMAN TWINS, looking grim, in third. DOUG looks stunned. KATE is beaming, blowing kisses to th house. THE CROWD ROARING. She turns for a different angle and loses her footing -- almost slipping off the platform
(catching her) You all right?
I’m wonderful! (she’s tipsy) And you’re wonderful too! . DOUG can’t believe what he’s just heard.
THIRTY REPORTERS crowded in this tight space. KATE and DOUG beside BRIAN and LORIE at a table answering question
Doug, what’s the difference between this and hockey?
The women. THE REPORTERS ROAR. KATE sneaks a sip from another beer.
Kate, what’s it like skating with this guy?
Doug? Doug is the best. He’s just the best! . DOUG looks over. She’s not tipsy, she’s drunk. Beyond her, LORIE is watching, measuring DOUG’s reaction.

A crush of PEOPLE: WELL-WISHERS, REPORTERS, SKATERS, COAC ETC. Flowers everywhere. JACK AND ANTON splipping through the CROWD, pass RICK TUTTLE giving an interview. JACK sto taps the REPORTER on the shoulder. He turns --
(weakly) Jack, Anton, congratulations.
(to the Reporter) This shark ever tries to deke me again, I'll give you a ‘story you’a kill for. TUTTLE pales. JACK and ANTON press on.

head_text.subj: THE FAR END OF THE HALLWAY -

text: Away from the crowd, KATE and DOUG alone in street clothe
We can’t just run out.
Of course we can! Come on... DOUG, unsure, glances back up the hallway to see LORIE an BRIAN surrounded by a CROWD OF WELL WISHERS.
(grabbing his hand) It’s our night. We can do whatever we want!
(confused) What’s going on here? I mean --
-- I thought you were the one who wanted to cut loose... (she smiles) You’re coming with me and that’s all there is to it.
91 : CUT To:

Lights shimmering in the moonlight. MUSIC UP -- we’re going into a MONTAGE here, a series of quick shots. -- A CAB stops in the heart of the French Quarter. KATE jumps out, ready to party. DOUG struggles to catch up. -- A CLUB ON BOURBON ST. Packed and hopping. KATE at the crowded bar, waving wildly for the BARTENDER. DOUG standi behind her, looking off-stride. -- CLUB #2. Wilder still. A ZYDECO BAND on stage, PATRONS DANCING and DRINKING. KATE and DOUG at a table. She finis the final sip of some tropical concoction. DOUG nursing a beer. KATE looks up, flags a passing WAITRESS. The WAITRE signals for another round. DOUG tries to wave her off, bu too late. ~-- CLUB #3. This place is really rocking. A BLUES BAND ON STAGE. The CROWD going nuts. DOUG watches KATE with disbelief -- she’s got her hair down, sweater off, chuggi yet another cocktail. Suddenly, she turns, takes his hand before he knows what’s happening she’s leading him out on the crowded dance floor. She’s a wild woman. DOUG can’t resist any longer -- they’re dancing. DISSOLVE. To:
REVEAL -- KATE wrapped around DOUG in an empassioned embr At least it’s passionate from her standpoint, DOUG yuits away -- catches his breath. \
We’re here. KATE looks up. .She’s bombed. DOUG leads her out.
THE DOOR TO KATE’S HOTEL ROOM -- MOMENTS LATER DOUG turns the key, opens the door, and stands aside.
Go on. KATE, leaning on him, looks up, focuses.
Aren’t you joining me?
Kate...
(sing-song blithering) ...Of course you are, you are, you are... She takes his hand, stumbling forward, pulling him into -
DOUG extracts his hand. KATE turns clumsily.
Aren’t you going to ask me te dance?
I don’t think so.

Oh, Doug...Douglas, silly thing, please, please don’t talk about thinking. That’s what I love about the way I feel right now. I feel — like even if I tried I couldn’t think and I’ve been thinking so much for so long and it’s sooococoe tiring... (she giggles) ...the world is spinning and spinning and spinning and I couldn’t care less... DOUG stands there. KATE begins to unbutton her blouse. KATE. -+-I/m looking at you and I’m seeing how you must’ve been as a little boy... (eyes weaving) .-.Hockey shirt hanging out. Bandaids on your knees... Her fingers fumble with the buttons. She’s really gone.

Did you ever play with magnets when you were little? -- Of course you did, everyone did. You know how you’d turn them one way and they’d push away? You’d run them around the table, pushing then, and then all you had to do was just flip them over and suddenly... (she smiles) ...don’t you see, that’s why everything’s been so awful... (the last button) ..-we just needed a little flip.  93
Not tonight, Kate. Not like this. She stands there. Her expression darkens.
Not like what? Not like me?
That’s not it. Kate, you’re bombed.
(trying to focus) What are you talking about?
You ought to sit down. Drink a lot of water. Try and get some --

(exploding) Oh God, just what I need -- somebody else telling me what to do! (she steps back, nearly falling) In case.you missed it, I’m throwing myself at you! (pulling her blouse around her) I’m standing here tearing off ny clothes and you’re giving me a rundown of drinking do’s and don’t’s!
I think maybe I know a little bit more about it than you.
I get enough coaching on the ice! DOUG stiffens. He stands there, lost for a moment.
Get out. DouG You’ve got this all wrong.
Do I ever! (bitterly) Excuse my surprise, but really... how disappointing -- God’s gift to reckless abandon revealed as nothing but a prude in wolf’s clothing!
What the hell does that mean?

It means I’m sick to death of your hormone-rattling sermons about the raptures of free-spirited behavior! She’s woosy, barely able to get this out and stay standin DOUG colors, stiffly trying to contain his anger.
You’re a lousy drunk.
And you’re a lousy date.
It didn’t have to be like this.
I said: Get out. DOUG turns, walking quickly back through the door -- and gone. KATE drops onto the bed.

INT. DOUG’S HOTEL ROOM -- LATER FOUR EMPTY MINI-BAR BOTTLES OF VODKA are lined up in a ro DOUG, shirt off, sits in the half darkness, staring out t window. He’s drinking, putting on the buzz he refrained { all night. He’s moved past the stage of trying to make se of the past twenty-four hours, now just drinking to put himself to sleep. A KNOCK AT THE DOOR. DOUG comes to. . He shakes his head, crosses the room.
(opening the door) Kate, I really -- LORIE PAULSEN stands there, dressed to kill, holding seve bouquets of flowers. She peeks inside.
You alone? . (Doug stands there, . speechless) You like roses? DOUG makes no move to take them. LORIE slides in past nia shutting the door behind her.
That’s one thing about skating, the fucking flowers can drive you crazy.
; DouG Lorie, listen... She slinks into the room, looking it over. LORIE ’ I waited for you. I guess we got our wires crossed.
Yeah. I guess.
(looking for a place for the roses) Must be nice for Kate, skating with a man who doesn’t keep a vase around. LORIE turns. She looks incredible.
I watched your program. You’ve got a great sit spin. (she smiles) I thought maybe we could trade secrets.

The sun just cresting the horizon. curt To: INT. KATE’S HOTEL ROOM ~~ ‘DAWN KATE asleep on the bed, fully clothed, just as we left he She rustles. Her eyes blink open painfully. And then, the sledgehammer throb of her first, epic, hangover. She groa And then her expression dissolves from pain to panic, as previous night’s events begin to leak back in.

KATE stands weakly before at a HOTEL ROOM DOOR. She stead herself, battling the pounding agony of her hangover. makes a half-hearted effort to pull herself together, wor her hair, rubbing her eyes, trying her injured best to lo She presentable. She summons a smile, and KNOCKS ON THE DOOR. A pause. And then the door opens. LORIE PAULSEN, holding only a pillow over her naked body, stands in the doorway.
I...I must have the wrong roon.
Yes. I’d say so. KATE starts to back away. LORIE standing there, when -- DOUG’S VOICE (groggily, from inside) What the hell’s going on? KATE freezes.

(to Kate) A little early for practice, isn’t it? DOUG, in the BG, pulls a sheet around him, coming for the door -- no idea what’s happening -- moving sleepily behin LORIE -- and then his jaw drops -- his eyes meet KATE’s. She turns -- bolting down the hallway --
oh shit... DOUG pushes past LORIE, rushing out into the hall, nearly colliding with SEVERAL HOTEL GUESTS exiting the next roon
-- Kate! Wait a minute...! Kate, come on, just --

(wheeling on him) -- You pig! You complete, total, unreedemable pig! (he stops cold) How? -- How could you? My God, to think I was coming to apologize and and all the while you were in there with her!

Kate, that’s not -- KATE . -- Don’t! Don’t even try! Don’t you dare say one more word! (Doug stands there) My God, just looking at you makes me sick! She turns away. The HOTEL GUESTS look on, shocked. SEVERAL OTHER DOORS pop open -=- more curious FACES.
(suddenly) Wait one fucking minute!
96  97 DOUG charges after her, the sheet flapping round him as h grabs for her -- KATE yanks herself free --
-- Get your hands off me! KATE strides for her door. DOUG struggling after.
Maybe I missed something along the way, but I don’t remember making promises to you about anything.
(pure disgust) -- my God... DOUG jumps between her and her room. MORE GUESTS peer out from doorways up and down the HALLWAY.
One question -- one -- Were you, or were you not, engaged to be married until the day before yesterday?
That is hardly the point!
Maybe you’d rather replay the moment you bounced me out of your room.
Count your blessings -- she might not have waited much longer.
That’s not how it happened.
‘You can spare me the details!

Fine! -- Then let me just hit the highlights: For fifteen months you act like I’m a cross between a trained dog and your worst nightmare. And then -- in the space of three hours -- I’m supposed to be falling at your feet, thanking ny lucky stars because you’ve just gotten drunk enough to decide I’m worthy of your attention. Well, excuse me, I’m really fucking sorry, but I can’t downshift that fast!
98 KATE pulls her key. Stares at him grimly. . KATE . Get out of my way. DOUG moves aside. KATE jams her key into the lock.
That’s all you have to say?

No. No, I have one more thing to add: From now on, from this minute until we finally, mercifully, go our separate ways, our relationship is strictly business. KATE ploughs into her room. The DOOR SLAMS SHUT. DOUG standing there, turns to see a DOZEN HOTEL GUESTS staring at hin. pouG : What the hell are you looking at?

KATE and DOUG taking off their skates. ANTON holding a stack of papers. The vibe is deadly. Past hostile. They direct all comments to ANTON: . KATE . Tell him he snaps my hand back on. that Salchow one more time it’s ~ going to take a week to count the pick marks up his back.

Tell her, she doesn’t put a little high test into that twist-lift it’s gonna take a month to soak the black and blue outta her landing gear. ANTON ignores this. Pulls a bench in front of then. Places something on the bench for their inspection.
Deffel and Frick. German. INSERT -- A. PHOTOGRAPH -- the first of a series -- WE’LL INTERCUT PICTURES AS NEEDED with ANTON’S COMMENTARY and KATE and DOUG’s reactions.
Height. Power. A triple outside Salchow. Much injuries.
oO ANTON turns the next picture.

Hastings and Mulgrew. Canadian National Champions. Big energy. But sloppy. (the next) Dubois and Gercel. French. Triple toe loop. Lutz twist. (the next) Neuman and Paulsen... (pointedly) +..we know their work. (the .next) Greka and Turgeyev. Russian. Gold medal Calgary. Two time world champions. And then three pictures in a row. KATE, bored until now - KATE shifts.
Who the hell is that?
Izuto and Tenaki.
Never heard of them.
Will be crushing news to them I am sure. Last night they win NHK Championships. One hand lasso lift into double Axel throw. Forward outside death spiral. Triple Salchow. Triple Axel twist.
Whoaa...
Izuto and Tenaki?
Japanese government enjoys surprise too. They are who we must beat. (he measures them) For gold, we must have slingshot triple. We start again tomorrow. DOUG starts putting his skates back on.
What are you doing? 99
(to Anton) Tell her, I’ve got another hour left in me. If she’s up to it.
KATE and DOUG, both wearing pads and helmets, working on the slingshot triple -- KATE speeding for the launch -- DOUG turns -- mis-steps -- they both fall --
Trying it again -- KATE in the air -- turning -- descendi -- falling past DOUG’s waiting arms -- landing on the ice
And again -- picking up speed -- rounding the turn -- int his arms -- just missing -- KATE landing hard --

(barking from the sidelines) We ! Is not power play, Douglas! And Katya, what is bullshit with free leg, eh? When I say to swing wide, am I speaking to myself? KATE and DOUG glower from the ice. Tempers tight.

Center ice -- Again! JACK enters to join ANTON on the sidelines as KATE and DO trudge back to center ice in the BG. The two men lean the a moment, watching KATE and DOUG wrangle into position, a then ANTON turns to JACK:
I need to know, what do we skate for, Jack? Medal or Gold?
You mean this new triple? You’re asking me? ANTON nods. A beat. JACK thinks a moment.
Let’s put it like this: in thirt years, can you remember how many second places you won?
(eyes on the ice) I just wanted to make sure.

A CLOSE ANGLE -- DOUG and KATE, no pads this time, flying across the ice -- very fast -- hand in hand -- now turnin -- into DOUG’s arms and he lifts and she’s up and -- SUPE SLO MOTION as -- KATE explodes:into the air -- the slings triple -- around -- and around -- and she’s losing it -- coming down -- too fast -- off balance -- grimacing -- an she hits the ice hard -- skidding away -- motionless and
INT. KATE’S BEDROOM -=- NIGHT SILENCE -- KATE bolts upright in bed. It was a dream.
KATE, in robe and slippers, staring at the EMPTY TROPHY C
Kate? KATE starts, turns. JACK is standing there.
I came down. I was looking at the pictures of mother.
She would’ve been so proud of you.
Really? You think she’d look at me, at what I am -- you think she’d be proud? KATE stares at him. ‘JACK suddenly uncomfortable.
You better get back to bed.
I can’t sleep.
You’1l be better off upstairs.
It’s funny how you or someone else always know where I’1l be better off.
What are we talking about, Kate?
